This story starts with some online Christmas shopping gone very wrong when in the winter of 2008, a guy named John Palmer of Clayton, Utah, decided to buy his wife, Jen, a couple of holiday tchotchkes from an online retailer called KlearGear.
Just some little desk toys, key chains, little nerdy things like that.
But Jen Palmer says the gifts never arrived, and after a testy back and forth with the company's customer service, she did what many thousands of consumers do every month.
She posted about her experience on an online business review site.
I posted the review, and then we forgot about it.

Saying that we had violated their non-disparagement clause and that we were now subject to a $3,500 fine if we didn't take the review down.
A non-disparagement clause.
That's a caveat in the fine print of a company's terms of service restricting or barring customers from publicly reviewing their experience with the company.
The Palmers told KlearGear they wouldn't be taking down the comment or paying the fine.
All we did was tell the truth, and you don't get to fine us for this.

Paul Levy is a lawyer with Public Citizen, a consumer rights advocacy group that agreed to represent the Palmers in court.

The purpose of a non-disparagement clause is to have a hammer with which to hit consumers who haven't said anything false, but you can make them take it down or you can seek damages, you can seek attorney fees, what might you.
Levy says these so-called gag clauses can limit truthful criticism and deprive consumers of valuable information.
They put a thumb on the scale of the marketplace of ideas.
After a lengthy legal back and forth, the Palmers won a default judgment in federal court and their credit was restored.
